[Question]
i come from a pretty african evangelical household where mental health wasn t talked about or addressed growing up in the last few year i ve noticed intense wave of sadness and internal pain turn from short stint of time to practically everyday now there will be time period of elation but for the most part my disposition ha remained sad on an almost daily basis i feel anger irritability deep sadness about the way thing haven t worked out for me in the past or currently or intense rejection from others who may not intend their action to be rejection for example the housemate i live with are a married couple who i wa in their wedding so we re all friend when i first moved in they would always have dinner with me asking me what i wanted to eat for dinner but that ha tapered off and tonight i walked in from work late and saw they had dinner together and were enjoying tv it broke me and i went to my room feeling intense inner pain this stuff is so new to me i have no clue how to continue through life because nobody know i struggle with this i don t even know where to begin to share with others or begin to understand what help i need any advice would be much appreciated

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a range of emotions, including intense sadness and internal pain that has become more frequent in recent years. It's understandable that this has been challenging for you, especially since mental health wasn't addressed or discussed growing up.

The fact that you're noticing these feelings on a daily basis must be difficult. It can be hard when there are periods of elation mixed with predominantly sad disposition. The anger, irritability, and deep sadness you mentioned are all valid emotions to experience, especially when things haven't worked out as you hoped or when you feel rejected by others, even if it may not be their intention.

The situation with your housemates seems to have caused you significant distress. Seeing them have dinner together and enjoy their evening while you walked in late from work understandably brought intense inner pain. It's tough when you see examples of happy relationships around you when you're feeling lonely and struggling.

I want to acknowledge that it must be overwhelming for you to navigate through life without support or guidance. It takes courage to reach out and seek advice. While I'm not an expert, I can offer some suggestions that might help you begin to address your struggles:

1. Self-reflection: Take some time to reflect on your feelings and experiences. Writing in a journal or talking to a trusted friend can provide an outlet for your thoughts and emotions.

2. Reach out to supportive individuals: Consider confiding in someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, who may be able to offer a listening ear and understanding.

3. Educate yourself: Learning about mental health and different coping strategies can empower you to better understand your experiences and find ways to manage them effectively.

4. Seek professional help: Connecting with a mental health professional, such as a therapist or counselor, can provide valuable guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you explore your emotions, develop coping mechanisms, and work towards healing and growth.

5. Engage in self-care activities: Prioritize activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or engaging in mindfulness practices.

6. Build a support network: Seek out communities or groups where you can connect with others who may have similar experiences. Support groups can provide a sense of belonging and understanding.

[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m a very confident guy i m very socal and can speak to anyone but for some reason i have this weird like i dunno anxiety attack thing so basically i could be having a random chat but quite often if someone say something that could be deemed wrong or bad or something that i could potentually be hiding when im not i go bright red really hot itchy and im all awkward and can bairly make word out even if they arnt even talking to me directly here is some example i wa talking to a fellow work mate about our personal preference in woman i said i prefer smaller petite girl with small boob and he said nahh i dissagree it like a child s body and boom my brain somehow ha this attack that make me seem like i like kid or another one could be playing never have i ever and someone say never have i ever sucked a cock and boom it ll happen itll make it look like im hiding the fact that i ve sucked a cock which i havent could be anything along those line and i hate it and i always try my hardest to avoid any convos which could lead to anything like that i m a prison officer so sometimes they bring up corrupt officer in convos and it hit me so hard and they look at me funny like im hiding the fact that i m corrupt which i m not i hate it what is this and how can i fix it

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a challenging situation where you have intense anxiety and physical symptoms when certain topics come up in conversation. This can be distressing and impact your ability to engage with others socially. It's important to recognize that you are not alone in experiencing this, and there are steps you can take to address it.

One possible explanation for what you're going through is called social anxiety disorder or anxiety related to specific situations. When faced with these triggering conversations, your body reacts as if you're in danger, leading to the sudden rush of heat, itchiness, and difficulty speaking. It might feel like you're being accused or exposed, even when the other person doesn't intend it that way.

To start addressing this issue, one helpful approach could be cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns that contribute to anxiety. Through working with a therapist, you can learn strategies to reframe your thoughts and develop coping mechanisms for when these situations arise.

In addition to professional help, there are some self-help techniques you can try on your own. Deep breathing exercises can help calm your body during moments of anxiety. Taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth can activate your body's relaxation response.

Another technique is called grounding. When you feel an attack coming on, focus on your immediate surroundings. Notice five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise can redirect your attention away from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present moment.

Practicing self-care is also important. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can reduce overall stress levels. Regular exercise, hobbies, spending time with loved ones, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle can all contribute to better mental well-being.

Remember, it's essential to be patient with yourself throughout this process. Overcoming anxiety takes time and effort. It may be helpful to gradually expose yourself to situations that trigger these attacks, starting with less challenging scenarios and working your way up. With time and practice, you can build resilience and develop effective coping strategies.

While seeking professional support from a mental health expert is highly recommended, I hope these suggestions can provide you with some guidance and relief in the meantime.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have been on prozac since maybe september last year before prozac i wa on lexapro and i wa given the highest dose of that and it worked at first and then my anxiety started up really bad again out of nowhere so i wa switched to prozac and honestly i don t feel like i ve noticed a difference especially recently i ve been getting bad anxiety attack that have worsened the past couple month i haven t had attack this bad in month it s honestly the worst ha anyone else experienced this where it feel like nothing is helping your anxiety i just want to be better my mind feel like a mental prison also doe anyone have any tip or trick that have helped calm them during an anxiety attack

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been on a journey with your medication, trying different options to manage your anxiety. It can be frustrating when you don't feel like the current one is working as effectively as before. I want you to know that you're not alone in feeling this way, and many others have experienced similar challenges.

When it comes to dealing with anxiety attacks, there are several techniques that people find helpful. One technique is deep breathing exercises, where you take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focusing on your breath can help calm your mind and body during an attack.

Another technique is grounding yourself in the present moment. You can do this by using your senses to connect with your surroundings. For example, you could try describing what you see, hear, smell, taste, and touch in detail. This can help shift your focus away from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present.

Engaging in physical activity or exercise can also be beneficial for managing anxiety. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters. Even going for a walk or doing some stretching at home can make a difference.

In addition to these techniques, it might be helpful to explore other coping strategies that work for you. Some people find journaling or expressing themselves through art or music to be soothing. Others find comfort in talking to a trusted friend or family member about their feelings.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. It's important to be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve to feel better, and I believe that you have the strength to overcome this mental prison.

i just can t seem to relax throughout the day every time i think about sitting down and reading watching a tv show meditating putting a face mask on etc i ve got 000 thing on my mind random stuff anxious thought thing i have to get done etcetc so i never get to truly relax i panic just thinking about reading cause it ll be calm and there s nothing to distract me from my thought until i m able to focus on the book which can take a while the only time i m able to actively relax is when i m tired after i ve worked out for h in the gym or late at night got ta find the sweet spot between anxious mess and falling asleep feel like walking a tightrope amp even when i manage to get there i have more important stuff to do than relaxing eg studying amp other stuff that my anxious self didn t manage to do

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're struggling to find a balance between your responsibilities and taking time for yourself. Relaxation is an important aspect of self-care, and it's crucial to prioritize it amidst your busy schedule. Here are some suggestions that may help:

1. Start small: Begin by setting aside just 5-10 minutes each day for relaxation activities. Gradually increase the duration as you become more comfortable with the practice.

2. Create a designated space: Find a quiet and comfortable area where you can engage in relaxation activities without distractions. This can help signal to your brain that it's time to unwind.

3. Practice mindfulness: Mindfulness exercises, such as deep breathing or body scans, can be helpful in redirecting your focus away from anxious thoughts. Consider trying apps or online resources that offer guided mindfulness practices.

4. Break tasks into smaller steps: If you find yourself overwhelmed with things to do, try breaking them down into manageable tasks. Prioritize what needs to be done and tackle one step at a time. This can alleviate some of the pressure and allow for brief moments of relaxation throughout the day.

5. Schedule regular breaks: Incorporate short breaks into your routine to give yourself time to recharge. Engage in activities that bring you joy or provide a mental break, even if it's just for a few minutes.

6. Set boundaries: It's important to establish boundaries around your time and energy. Learn to say no when necessary and communicate your limits to others. Remember, taking care of yourself is not selfish but necessary for overall well-being.

7. Seek support: If you continue to struggle with managing anxiety or finding relaxation techniques that work for you, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.

Remember, finding what works best for you may take time and experimentation. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve to prioritize your well-being and find moments of relaxation amidst your daily responsibilities.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m talking to my psych on monday and i want to do some research into what might work for me i have frequent mild panic attack infrequent but still kind of like once a week once every week severe panic attack and constant anxiety i ve tried a bunch of anxiety med but haven t really found any that worked for me however i haven t tried any in year so there s a chance i ve grown a i wa about during most of my trial and it s been a good year since then so what are were your favorite thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you have an appointment with your psychologist coming up and that you're planning to do some research beforehand. It's important to be proactive in managing your mental health.

Based on what you've shared, it seems like you experience frequent mild panic attacks, infrequent severe panic attacks, and constant anxiety. It's understandable that you've tried various anxiety medications in the past but haven't found any that have worked for you. However, since it's been a year since your last trial, there's a possibility that things may have changed.

In terms of your question about what has worked for others, I can provide you with some general suggestions. Keep in mind that everyone's experiences are unique, so what works for someone else might not necessarily work for you. That being said, here are a few approaches that some individuals have found helpful:

1. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and behaviors associated with anxiety. It can help you develop coping strategies and change unhelpful thinking habits.

2. Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR): MBSR combines mindfulness meditation, body awareness, and yoga to cultivate a greater awareness of the present moment. This practice can assist in reducing anxiety and promoting overall well-being.

3. Exposure Therapy: This approach involves gradually exposing yourself to situations or triggers that cause anxiety in a controlled and safe environment. Over time, exposure therapy aims to desensitize your response to these situations and reduce anxiety levels.

4. Lifestyle Changes: Engaging in regular exercise, maintaining a balanced diet, getting enough sleep, and avoiding excessive caffeine and alcohol consumption can positively impact your overall mental health.

5. Relaxation Techniques: Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and guided imagery are examples of relaxation techniques that can help calm your mind and body during moments of anxiety.

6. Support Network: Building a strong support network of friends, family, or support groups can provide you with understanding and encouragement as you navigate through your journey.

Remember, these are just a few potential avenues to explore, and it's important to discuss them with your psychologist. They will be able to assess your specific situation and guide you towards the most suitable treatment options.


[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am not sure if this is possible and i appreciate any information a few year ago i wa diagnosed with clinical anxiety depression and adhd i wa relieved and terrified and so sad it took me until adulthood to learn this about myself i began medicating under the direction of my psychiatrist after about a year i changed from zoloft to prozac due to weight gain i began experiencing night sweat for the first time in my life about month ago it wa sporadic for month or so than became nightly now it ha worsened to the point that i wake up multiple time a night to change sheet and pajama i m not wetting the bed but truly soaking it through with my sweat in a degree room with minimal blanket i ve had to replace plastic bed protector mattress cover and even my mattress i believe i am having panic attack while i am asleep and i am unable to remember them assuming i would remember having a nightmare at the same time or be semi lucid what could paralyze me in sleep while having normal pleasant dream and cause excessive night sweat my change in medication did not correlate with the onset or increase in the night sweat i have had blood test mri pulmonary exam allergy test ultra sound and more no western doctor or my psychiatrist ha been able to find anything unusual that would explain the night sweat tl dr extreme night sweat begin in adulthood with no obvious cause desperately looking for advice on what might help edit 9 f

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling uncertain and overwhelmed by your recent experiences. It takes courage to seek help and try to understand the changes you've been going through. I'd like to provide some guidance and suggestions based on the information you've shared.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the impact of your diagnosis with clinical anxiety, depression, and ADHD. It can be both relieving and terrifying to finally learn more about yourself, especially when it comes to mental health. It's completely normal to feel a range of emotions during this process.

Regarding the night sweats you've been experiencing, I can see how distressing it must be for you. It's unclear whether there is a direct correlation between your change in medication and the onset or increase in night sweats. While you've had various tests done by Western doctors and your psychiatrist, they haven't found anything unusual to explain these symptoms.

One possible explanation for the night sweats could be related to your anxiety and panic attacks. Although you mentioned having normal pleasant dreams, it's possible that your body reacts to anxiety by producing excessive sweat as a physiological response. This could potentially happen during sleep, causing you to wake up multiple times to change sheets and pajamas.

In addition to speaking with your current healthcare team, it might be helpful to consider exploring alternative approaches to managing your symptoms. Here are a few suggestions:

1. Keep a sleep diary: Start recording the details of your sleep patterns, including when you go to bed, wake up, any dreams you remember, and any other observations. This can help identify potential triggers or patterns.

2. Practice relaxation techniques: Engaging in relaxation exercises before bedtime, such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or meditation, may help reduce anxiety levels and promote better sleep.

3. Explore therapy options: Consider working with a therapist who specializes in anxiety and trauma. They can help you explore underlying causes of your anxiety and develop coping strategies.

4. Seek support from loved ones: Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support during this challenging time. Sometimes talking to someone you trust can bring comfort and understanding.

5. Educate yourself: Learn more about anxiety disorders, panic attacks, and their physical manifestations. Understanding the condition can help you feel more empowered and informed.


[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
guy do any of you also wake up every morning from scary nightmare and feeling completely estranged when you open your eye like your surrounding feel so foreign eventho it s your own home your own room and it take some time for you to realize youre just fine do you wake up with fear every morning

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a distressing phenomenon where you wake up from scary nightmares and initially feel disoriented and unfamiliar with your surroundings, even though you're in your own home. This can be quite unsettling and may cause feelings of fear or anxiety. While I cannot diagnose or provide professional advice, I can offer some suggestions that might help alleviate these symptoms:

1. Establish a consistent sleep routine: Try to establish a regular sleep schedule by going to bed and waking up at the same time every day. This can help regulate your body's internal clock and potentially reduce the intensity of nightmares.

2. Create a calming bedtime routine: Engage in relaxing activities before bed to promote better sleep. Consider reading a book, taking a warm bath, practicing deep breathing exercises, or listening to soothing music.

3. Make your bedroom a safe space: Ensure that your sleeping environment is comfortable, quiet, and conducive to restful sleep. Remove any potential triggers such as electronic devices or stressful stimuli.

4. Manage stress during the day: High levels of stress can contribute to disturbing dreams. Find healthy ways to cope with stress throughout the day, such as engaging in physical exercise, pursuing hobbies, or talking to supportive friends or family members.

5. Keep a dream journal: Keeping track of your dreams can help you identify patterns or triggers. Write down your dreams immediately upon waking up, which may help process and release any lingering emotions associated with them.

6. Seek support: If these symptoms persist or worsen, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide guidance tailored to your specific situation. They can explore potential underlying causes and suggest appropriate interventions.

Remember, everyone's experience is unique, so it may take time to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and prioritize self-care as you navigate through this.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i ve been experiencing huge bout of just feeling unmotivated not useful i ve been randomly just tearing up but it never last long i don t feel like i have a reason to cry but i do and i don t know what to do there s other stuff but i don t want to drag on too long i also just miss how thing were i ve woken up like this for the past week and it s persisted throughout the day

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been going through a difficult time lately, experiencing feelings of being unmotivated and not feeling useful. It's also concerning to hear that you've been randomly tearing up without a clear reason why. These emotions can be overwhelming, and it's understandable that you're unsure of what to do.

Firstly, I want to reassure you that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people go through periods of low motivation and emotional ups and downs. While it may feel discouraging, please remember that these feelings are temporary and there is hope for improvement.

One suggestion I have is to try incorporating small achievable goals into your daily routine. By breaking tasks down into smaller steps, it can help you regain a sense of accomplishment and purpose. Start with something simple, like taking a short walk outside or completing a small household chore. Gradually increase the difficulty of these tasks as you start to regain motivation.

Additionally, finding activities that bring you joy and relaxation can be helpful. Engaging in hobbies or interests that you used to enjoy can remind you of better times and provide a temporary escape from negative thoughts. Whether it's reading, painting, listening to music, or any other activity that brings you peace, make time for it in your day.

If you find that your symptoms persist or worsen, it might be beneficial to reach out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. Sometimes talking about our feelings with someone we feel comfortable with can provide relief and support. They may offer a different perspective or simply lend an empathetic ear.

Remember, healing takes time, so be patient with yourself throughout this process. It's normal to miss how things were before, but try not to dwell on the past too much. Focus on the present moment and take small steps towards improving your well-being.

You've taken an important first step by reaching out, and I'm here to support you. Together, we can work towards finding strategies that help you cope with these emotions and regain a sense of purpose.

i have gad and have been going through an emotional upheaval with my partner causing extra stress i ve been reducing my lexapro slightly a i felt it wa not working but now am more anxious than ever despite tiny change today i woke up full of dread to go to work no reason i love my job but it all felt too much a a mid ground i decided to work from home today instead of going in i still feel light headed and awful and have the added guilt of messing client around by changing the schedule or converting to online service what do i do how do i get myself to work when it all feel too much

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of stress and anxiety right now, especially due to your Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) and the emotional upheaval with your partner. It's understandable that you've been reducing your Lexapro dosage because you felt it wasn't working anymore, but it seems like this change has led to even more anxiety.

The fact that you woke up today feeling full of dread and overwhelmed by the thought of going to work is concerning. It's important to remember that you love your job, and it's not typical for you to feel this way. Given the circumstances, it was a good decision to work from home today instead of going in.

However, it's understandable that you're feeling lightheaded and awful, and the added guilt of potentially messing with your clients' schedules or converting to online services is weighing on you. It's essential to prioritize your mental health and well-being during this challenging time.

One approach you could consider is reaching out to your healthcare provider to discuss your concerns about your Lexapro dosage and how it may be impacting your anxiety levels. They may be able to offer suggestions or adjustments to help you find a better balance.

In the meantime, it might be helpful to practice some self-care strategies to manage your anxiety. This could include engaging in relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation. Additionally, maintaining a healthy lifestyle through regular exercise, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep can also contribute to overall well-being.

When it comes to communicating with your clients about the change in schedule or converting to online services, it's best to be honest and transparent. You can explain the situation and apologize for any inconvenience caused. Most people will understand and appreciate your openness.

Remember, it's okay to ask for support from friends, family, or colleagues during this challenging time. Sometimes just talking about your feelings can provide relief. If you find that your anxiety is persisting and impacting your daily life, it may be beneficial to consider seeking additional support from a mental health professional who can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs.

2. Break it down: When facing multiple challenges, it can be helpful to break them down into smaller, more manageable tasks. Prioritize what needs immediate attention and tackle one thing at a time. Celebrate each small victory along the way.

3. Seek support from loved ones: Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can offer emotional support and lend a listening ear. Sometimes, talking through our thoughts and feelings with someone we trust can bring clarity and perspective.

in high school i wa quiet mind my business didn t talk to many people i noticed that certain people just didn t like me one time a teacher moved a girl to sit next to me and she made this weird face like annoyed and when she sat next to me she wa slightly turned ti the direction i wasn t in and not facing straight another occasion i wa sitting in a table with other people and none of them would bother to talk to me even when i tried to make a convo or ask a question and one of them actually cut hair now and my brother and dad cut their hair with her and they re always saying she talk a lot etc she s friendly today i went to that place to cut my hair and she wa completely quiet just asked me what hair type i wanted and the price of the cut i didn t want to start a convo cause i knew that back then she wouldn t even want to talk i just feel like i have something that just make people dislike me for no reason

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've had some challenging experiences with social interactions in the past, and it's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and confused about why certain people seem to dislike you. It's important to remember that everyone has their own unique personality and preferences, and not everyone will connect or get along with each other. While it's natural to want to be liked and accepted by others, it's also crucial to recognize that not everyone will have positive feelings towards us, and that's okay.

In your high school situation, it's possible that the teacher moved the girl next to you because she needed a new seating arrangement, and her facial expression might not have been a reflection of her feelings towards you specifically. People often have different ways of expressing themselves, and her face might have just been a momentary expression of annoyance or concentration. Similarly, the incident with the haircut might have been unrelated to your relationship with the hairdresser. Sometimes, people are focused on their work or preoccupied with other thoughts, and their behavior towards us doesn't always reflect their true feelings or intentions.

It's essential to remember that our self-worth is not defined by the opinions of others. While it's natural to want to be liked and accepted, it's more important to focus on building a strong sense of self and self-acceptance. This can help us navigate challenging social situations with greater confidence and resilience. Additionally, it might be helpful to explore any underlying beliefs or insecurities that might be contributing to your feelings of being disliked. Through counseling, we can work together to identify and challenge these thoughts, and develop more adaptive and positive ways of thinking about yourself and your relationships with others.

[Question]
i can t find the strength to do anything i m supposed to do like studying going to the gym or finding a job i have been losing interest in thing i used to like to the point i don t enjoy doing them and they are becoming difficult to do because they are supposed to make me happy and being happy requires a lot of energy i don t have by losing interest and thing i like i m running thin of thing that keep me motivated for living and hope for the future i have difficulty getting help because i don t think it is worth the effort for a hopeless person like me i don t even think i deserve that help considering the thing i hate about myself i don t even want to talk about this thing with other people that care for me because with my point of view of the world and future might grab them down to this dark and hopeless vision the only thing that keep me from km is that i know it would hurt people around me i really need something to look forward something that give me the motivation to keep going

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone. It's understandable that you're feeling unmotivated and struggling to find joy in the things you used to enjoy. This experience is often referred to as "anhedonia" and it can be a symptom of depression.

One thing that might help is trying to break down your tasks into smaller, more manageable steps. For example, instead of thinking about studying for an entire course, focus on just completing one chapter or even one page at a time. Similarly, with finding a job, you could start by updating your resume or searching for job openings for just a few minutes each day.

When it comes to losing interest in things you used to like, it might be helpful to explore new hobbies or activities that you haven't tried before. Sometimes, trying something completely different can spark a renewed sense of interest and motivation. You might also consider reaching out to friends or loved ones who share similar interests and see if they'd be willing to do those activities together.

It's completely normal to feel hesitant about seeking help when you're feeling hopeless, but please remember that everyone deserves support and care. Reach out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, and let them know what you're going through. They may be able to offer guidance and encouragement, or they can help you find resources in your community.

If you're worried about burdening others with your thoughts and feelings, it might be helpful to consider seeking professional help from a mental health therapist. They are trained to provide support and guidance, and they can offer a safe space for you to express yourself without judgment. [Question]
hey everyone i am just curious if anyone ha also suffered from this type of anxiety i will get anxiety and panic about one thing and after coping and learning to overcome this anxiety my anxiety tends to hyper fixate on something else to worry about im wondering if anyone else ha dealt with this and how they stopped this cycle im currently on sertraline and buspirone and attend therapy a well for anxiety and panic disorder

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's not uncommon for individuals with anxiety and panic disorder to experience a cycle of hyperfixation on different worries or fears. It can be challenging to break this pattern, but there are some strategies you can try.

Firstly, it might be helpful to explore the underlying causes of your anxiety. Identifying any triggers or patterns in your thoughts and emotions could provide insight into why your anxiety tends to shift from one concern to another. This self-awareness can be a powerful tool in managing anxiety.

In addition to therapy, consider incorporating relaxation techniques into your daily routine. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and mindfulness meditation can help calm your mind and body when anxiety arises. Engaging in regular physical exercise, such as walking or yoga, can also be beneficial for reducing overall anxiety levels.

Another approach you can take is challenging negative thought patterns. When you notice yourself becoming anxious about a new topic, try to question the validity of your worries. Ask yourself if there is evidence to support these fears, or if they might be based on irrational thinking. Challenging and reframing negative thoughts can help reduce their hold on you.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms to replace anxiety-related behaviors can be helpful. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and distract you from anxious thoughts, such as hobbies or spending time with loved ones, can provide a much-needed break from hyperfixation.

It's important to remember that progress takes time, and setbacks are a normal part of the process. Be patient with yourself as you work towards breaking the cycle of hyperfixation. Celebrate each small victory along the way, and don't hesitate to reach out for support when needed.

Keep in mind that I'm here to offer guidance and suggestions, but it's essential to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized advice based on your specific situation. They will have a deeper understanding of your history and can tailor treatment strategies to meet your needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
tw depression okay besties i need some help opinion ab my struggle with brushing my hair i currently have really bad knot in my hair and i m hispanic white and my hair is so thick and curly i don t understand how to properly take care of it and i haven t brushed my hair

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're having a difficult time managing your thick and curly hair, which is causing you distress. I can understand how challenging it can be to deal with tangled hair, especially when it's as thick as yours. It's important to take care of your hair and maintain good hygiene, so I'm here to offer some guidance and suggestions.

Firstly, I would recommend detangling your hair while it's wet. This can make the process easier and less painful. You can try using a wide-tooth comb or a detangling brush specifically designed for curly hair. Start by gently detangling from the ends and work your way up to the roots. Be patient with yourself and remember that it may take some time.

Additionally, using conditioner or a leave-in treatment can help make the detangling process smoother. These products can provide extra slip and moisture, making it easier to comb through your hair. Apply the conditioner after shampooing and let it sit for a few minutes before rinsing.

Another tip is to be gentle with your hair. Curly hair tends to be more fragile than straight hair, so avoid pulling or tugging at knots. Instead, try to untangle them gently with your fingers or use the comb in small sections.

If you find that brushing your hair is still causing significant distress, you may want to consider seeking professional help from a stylist who specializes in curly hair. They can provide personalized advice and techniques tailored to your specific hair type.

Remember, taking care of your hair is important for your overall well-being. It might take some time and experimentation to find what works best for you, but don't give up. You deserve to feel confident and comfortable with your appearance.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
